prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) in COSMOS 824759
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the CO(4-3) molecular gas in COSMOS 824759 in the extended configuration C36-7 in band 6, for a resolution of 0.05".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Extrapolating Larson's relation between the velocity dispersion and the size of giant molecular clouds (Larson 1981, Solomon et al. 1989) to high-redshift kpc-sized clumps, we expect a line width of about 50 km/s per clump. We select to observe the line data at a channel width of about 8 km/s and the continuum data at the maximum, namely 34.811 km/s. We will later further smooth the data.

We request an angular resolution of 0.05" in band 6, which corresponds to 0.3 kpc at z=0.7. Such a resolution is needed to detect the different star-forming clumps, whose size distribution is expected to start around 0.3 kpc according to observations and simulations (e.g., Forster Schreiber et al. 2011, Ceverino et al. 2012). Observed star-forming clumps at high-redshift have diameters up to 1.5 - 2.5 kpc (Elmegreen et al. 2004, Elmegreen & Elmegreen 2005, Elmegreen et al. 2007, Forster Schreiber et al. 2011), hence the largest angular scale (0.5", or 3 kpc at z=0.7).

We estimate the expected CO(4-3) fluxes from our IRAM PHIBSS2 CO(2-1) measurements. A complementary ALMA project specifically aims at better constraining the CO excitation in such galaxies (2015.1.01212.S, PI: Axel Weiss), but we provisionally take a conservative CO(4-3)/CO(2-1) line ratio of 2 (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). To estimate the expected flux per substructure on the CO(4-3) map, we assume that the total velocity-integrated flux is equally distributed among 7 substructures of ~1 kpc size spanning dv = 50 km/s each. We choose the sensitivity to have a S/N of at least 6 over velocity channels of width dv/3 = 16.7 km/s. We further use a line-to-continuum ratio of 10 (Combes et al. 1999) to estimate the expected continuum flux s_continuum >0.3 mJy. As the continuum will be smoothed in frequency at about 8 GHz, its S/N is not limiting: in each 0.05" beam where we detect CO(4-3) at S/N > 6 with a spectral resolution of 16.7 km/s, we expect to detect the continuum at S/N > 14. Moreover, with 7 clumps per galaxy on average and a S/N > 6 for their CO(4-3) line, stacking the different clumps should enable us to detect outflows whose intensity is about 15% of the line luminosity with the same S/N. We designed the science goals so as to minimize the total observing time given the requested sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a high-resolution CO line and dust continuum imaging program of a sample of six massive star-forming galaxies at z=0.7 in order to investigate in detail the star formation processes and the fate of the star-forming regions after the peak epoch of star formation. We will derive the mass distribution, the kinematics and the velocity dispersion of the molecular gas with an unprecedented resolution at this redshift, namely 0.05" or 300 parsecs, thus reaching the scales of the star-forming regions themselves. This will enable us to characterize star formation on subgalactic scales, notably through a spatially-resolved Kennicutt-Schmidt relation, to observe the inner morphology of the disk, and to test the virialization of the star-forming clumps. This study is meant as a high-resolution step forward of the IRAM PHIBSS and PHIBSS2 programs, which investigate early galaxy evolution and star formation from a larger statistical sample of about 200 sources at different redshifts but with lower resolution. ALMA resolution and sensitivity will allow us to reach sub-kpc scales, which is crucial to our understanding of the transitional period of the winding-down of star formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.01212.S, Molecular gas excitation in z=0.7 main sequence galaxies, PI: Axel Weiss
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00178.S, High resolution imaging of two massive star-forming galaxies at z=0.7, PI: Jonathan Freundlich
